{{multiple issues| {{COI|date=June 2017}} {{advert|date=June 2017}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Appota Corporation | logo = Appota-logo.png | logo_size = 250px | type = Corporation | founded = December 12, 2011 | hq_location = Building 11 (LE Building), Alley 71, Lang Ha St., Ba Dinh Dist., Hanoi, Vietnam. | industry = [[Game Publishing]]
[[Advertisement]]
Payment | products = Gamota - Game Publishing
AppotaX
Appota e-Wallet
Payhub
Gamehub: Mobile Game Media Portal
LNY - Appota Calendar Application
Appota Card
Appota Reports
Wifi Chua | num_employees = 300 - 350 | website = https://appota.com/ }} '''Appota Corporation''' is a mobile app service provider in Vietnam with three business services: [[Video game publisher|game publishing]], [[Mobile advertising|advertisement]], and [[Mobile payment|payment]].{{Cite news|url=http://dantri.com.vn/may-tinh-di-dong/com-con-duong-dan-toi-thanh-cong-20160920095158594.htm|title=.com - Con đường dẫn tới thành công|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2017-05-31|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=vi-VN}} The company's inventory system has 55 million users and 5 Million MAU.{{Cite web|url=https://e27.co/vietnams-appota-raises-series-c-valuation-closing-us50m-20170405/|title=Vietnam's Appota raises Series C, valuation closing in on US$50M|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In 2017, Appota closed an undisclosed Series C round from Korea Investment Partners and Mirae Asset Venture Investment.{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/appota-series-c-funding-round|title=Vietnam’s Appota scores series C funding as mobile gaming booms|last=|first=|date=|website=www.techinasia.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-31}} This is Appota's third funding round since its inception more than 5 years ago. Appota secured a series A round from VNP-Group in 2012, and a series B round from Golden Gate Venture and GMO Global Payment Fund in 2014.{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/appota-series-b|title=Appota, Vietnamese mobile content platform, secures series B funding|last=|first=|date=|website=www.techinasia.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-31}} Appota regularly provides Vietnam mobile market insights through its comprehensive market reports and supports the local startup community through various events’ sponsorship. The company has earned prominent startup awards, including “Most Disruptive Company” (by the Founder Institute) in 2012{{Cite web|url=https://e27.co/appota-vietnams-mobile-content-marketplace-named-founder-institutes-most-disruptive-graduate/|title=Appota, Vietnam’s mobile content marketplace, named Founder Institute’s most disruptive graduate|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} and “Vietnam’s most potential startup of 2013”.{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/vietnam-2015-light-at-the-end-of-the-tunnel|title=Tech in Asia - Connecting Asia's startup ecosystem|website=www.techinasia.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-04}} There are 3 subsidiary companies owned by Appota Group: Gamota (Game publishing company), Adsota (Advertisement company) and Appota Pay (Payment solution company). Appota’s headquarter is in Hanoi and extend its business to HCMC, Indonesia, and Singapore.{{Cite web|url=https://appota.com/contact.html|title=Contact Page|website=Appota.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-31}} == History == '''12/12/2011,''' Appota was founded in the first Topica Founder Institute in Vietnam. '''07/2012,''' Received the Most Disruptive Award from Founder Institute. '''11/2012,''' Delivered marketing service for international branches including NHN, UC, Kakao and Zepto Labs. '''26/01/2013,''' Received “Vietnam’s Most Potential Tech Startup Award”.{{Cite news|url=https://e27.co/appota-wins-vietnams-most-potential-tech-startup-award-2012/|title=Appota wins Vietnam's Most Potential Tech Startup Award 2012|newspaper=e27|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://fi.co/posts/7241|title=FI.co: Congratulations to the Winners of the 2013 Founder Institute Graduate Awards|website=The Founder Institute|access-date=2016-12-19}} '''03/2013,''' Setup the first oversea office in Singapore. '''04/2013,''' Set up business representative offices in HCM city & Indonesia. '''9/2013,''' Presented onClan, the first gaming social network for mobile gamers, in TechCrunch Disrupt 2013 in San Francisco. '''04/2014,''' Launched Gamehub, the first game portal specialized for mobile gamers. '''12/2014,''' 22 million users in Vietnam and Southest Asia on Appota platform. '''01/2015,''' Launched Applancer, the global mobile outsourcing platform. '''09/2015,''' Introduced Appota Pay, Adsota. '''2016,''' Changed the slogan to "Technology For Change". '''02/2017''', Appota launched AppotaX, a Mobile Ad Optimization Solution for mobile publishers based on Google Ad Exchange Platform.{{Cite web|url=http://ictnews.vn/kinh-doanh/ra-mat-appotax-giup-canh-bao-som-cac-vi-pham-tren-kho-tai-google-play-149588.ict|title=Ra mắt AppotaX giúp cảnh báo sớm các vi phạm trên kho tải Google Play|last=Ictnews|website=ictnews.vn|language=vi-vn|access-date=2017-05-31}} '''03/2017''', Appota closed an undisclosed Series C round from Korea Investment Partners and Mirae Asset Venture Investment.{{Cite news|url=http://vietnamnet.vn/vn/cong-nghe/ung-dung/appota-goi-von-thanh-cong-tu-quy-dau-tu-han-quoc-365196.html|title=Appota gọi vốn thành công từ hai quỹ đầu tư Hàn Quốc|last=News|first=VietNamNet|work=VietNamNet|access-date=2017-05-31}} '''10/2017''', Adsota became The Official Facebook Agency in Vietnam '''01/2018,''' Adsota Vietnam received a strategic investment from Korea's TNK Factory to conquer Southeast Asia's mobile advertising market '''03/2018''', Appota announces the fully acquisition of WiFi Chùa == Products and Services == === Digital content and online entertainment === ==== Gamota ==== Gamota is one of the three main game publishers leading Vietnamese market{{Cite news|url=http://game4v.com/game-mobile/4-nha-phat-hanh-se-lam-khuynh-dao-thi-truong-game-mobile-viet-nam-200214.g4v|title=4 nhà phát hành sẽ làm khuynh đảo thị trường game mobile Việt Nam|date=2015-05-26|work=Game4V|access-date=2017-05-31|language=en-US}} with games such as: Ai My Nhan Mobile, Y Thien, Captain Strike, Tu Dai Danh Bo.[[:vi:Danh sách trò chơi của công ty Gamota|Danh sách trò chơi của Gamota]] ==== Gamehub ==== Gamehub is a mobile game review portal ==== Lich Nhu Y ==== Lich Nhu Y is the first calendar that can connect between digital calendar content and table calendar via QR code.{{Cite news|url=http://genk.vn/apps-games/xem-lich-am-tu-vi-va-cung-hoang-dao-voi-ung-dung-lich-nhu-y-20150408161319356.chn|title=Xem lịch âm, tử vi và cung hoàng đạo với ứng dụng Lịch Như Ý|last=|first=|date=2015-04-10|work=genk.vn|access-date=2017-05-31|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=vi-VN}} ==== Wifi chua ==== The number one WiFi-enabled search and sharing application in Vietnam, top 100 apps for 4 years at a marketing cost of $ 0 === Payment and E-Commerce === ==== Appota Wallet ==== Appota Wallet is the first e-Wallet that offer cash-back service in Vietnam.{{Cite web|url=http://www.doanhnhansaigon.vn/thoi-su-trong-nuoc/startup-fintech-viet-thu-hut-nhieu-nha-dau-tu-ngoai/1104349/|title=Startup fintech Việt thu hút nhiều nhà đầu tư ngoại - doanhnhansaigon.vn|website=Báo Doanh Nhân Sài Gòn|language=vi-VN|access-date=2017-05-31}} ==== Appota Card ==== Prepaid card published by Appota which help users easily to top-up and purchase in-game items. === Advertisement === ==== AppotaX ==== Mobile Ad Optimization Solution for Publisher on Google Ad Exchange Platform.{{Cite news|url=http://vietnamnet.vn/vn/cong-nghe/ung-dung/giai-phap-appotax-cho-quang-cao-tren-ung-dung-di-dong-358165.html|title=Ra mắt giải pháp quảng cáo cho ứng dụng di động AppotaX|last=News|first=VietNamNet|work=VietNamNet|access-date=2017-05-31}}{{Cite news|url=http://baodautu.vn/trinh-lang-giai-phap-appotax-giup-tang-doanh-thu-quang-cao-cho-ung-dung-di-dong-d59271.html|title=Trình làng giải pháp AppotaX giúp tăng doanh thu quảng cáo cho ứng dụng di động|last=baodautu.vn|work=baodautu|access-date=2017-05-31}} ==== Adsota ==== Adsota is a mobile app marketing platform{{Cite web|url=http://ictnews.vn/the-gioi-so/di-dong/google-thi-truong-viet-nam-co-ty-le-ung-dung-vi-pham-chinh-sach-kha-cao-148381.ict|title=Google: Thị trường Việt Nam có tỷ lệ ứng dụng vi phạm chính sách khá cao|last=Ictnews|website=ictnews.vn|language=vi-vn|access-date=2017-05-31}} '''18/01/2018''', Adsota Vietnam has received a strategic investment from Korea’s TNK Factory to conquer Southeast Asia's mobile advertising market{{Cite web|url=https://www.dealstreetasia.com/stories/skorea-tnk-factory-investment-vietnam-adsota-90600/|title=South Korea's TNK Factory makes seven-digit investment in Vietnam's Adsota|website=www.dealstreetasia.com|access-date=2018-01-19}} == Mission == The Internet and mobile connection are among the fastest growing and most innovative technologies. In developing countries, they give people a whole new level of global connectivity, and bring access to opportunities that people would not have had before. Appota believes in the power of the Mobile Internet Technologies. We aspire to make mobile platforms that create opportunities and improve people’s lives and experiences in developing nations. == Appota Culture == Appota has built a professional working environment that is dynamic, modern, youth driven, Vietnamese based, and internationally inspired. In our open environment, employees have the opportunity to maximize their expertise, creativity, and gaming passion.{{Cite news|url=http://kenh14.vn/gamota-diem-den-moi-chuan-khong-can-chinh-cho-dan-cong-so-2017041217052111.chn|title=Gamota – Điểm đến mới "chuẩn không cần chỉnh" cho dân công sở|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2017-05-31|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=vi}} At Appota, employees do not have to navigate relationships between superiors and subordinates, but instead, a culture where there are “No Bosses, only Leaders”. == References == == External links == * [https://appota.com Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Appota}} [[Category:Advertisements]] [[Category:Vietnamese brands]] [[Category:Online companies]] [[Category:E-commerce]] [[Category:Companies of Vietnam]] [[Category:Information technology companies of Vietnam]] [[Category:Companies based in Hanoi]] [[Category:Companies established in 2011]]

{{Use British English|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox song | name = Arabian Knights | cover = Siouxsie Arabian.gif | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]] | album = [[Juju (Siouxsie and the Banshees album)|Juju]] | B-side = "Supernatural Thing", "Congo Conga" | released = 24 July 1981 | format = 7" and 12" vinyl | recorded = 1981 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Post-punk]] | length = 3:08 | label = [[Polydor Records|Polydor]] | writer = [[Siouxsie Sioux|Susan Ballion]], [[Budgie (musician)|Peter Edward Clarke]], [[John McGeoch]] and [[Steven Severin]] | producer = {{flatlist| * [[Nigel Gray]] * Siouxsie and the Banshees }} | chronology = Siouxsie and the Banshees | prev_title = [[Spellbound (Siouxsie and the Banshees song)|Spellbound]] | prev_year = 1981 | next_title = [[Fireworks (Siouxsie and the Banshees song)|Fireworks]] | next_year = 1982 | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[Siouxsie]] | type = single | prev_title = Spellbound | prev_year = 1981 | title = Arabian Knights | year = 1981 | next_title = [[Wild Things (EP)|Wild Things]] | next_year = 1981 }} }} "'''Arabian Knights'''" is a song by English [[post-punk]] band [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]]. The track was written by Siouxsie and the Banshees and co-produced with Nigel Gray. It was released in 1981 as the second and final single released from their fourth studio album, ''[[Juju (Siouxsie and the Banshees album)|Juju]]''. == Content and release == [[Siouxsie Sioux|Siouxsie]] later commented on the lyrics: "With 'Arabian Knights' it was quite a thrill to get the word 'orifices' on the radio".{{cite journal |last=Tilston |first=Lisa |date=11 November 1989 |title=Creature Comforts |magazine=[[Record Mirror]]}} The [[B-side]], "[[Supernatural Thing (song)|Supernatural Thing]]", was originally recorded by [[Ben E. King]], appearing on his 1975 album ''[[Supernatural (Ben E. King album)|Supernatural]]''. The extra B-side, "Congo Conga", was misspelled as "Conga Conga" on the U.S. edition of the 12". "Arabian Knights" was released on 24 July 1981 by record label [[Polydor Records|Polydor]]. The single peaked at number 32 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] in 1981.{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/Artist/17098/SIOUXSIE-AND-THE-BANSHEES |title=Siouxsie & the Banshees [uk charts] |work=[[Official Charts Company|officialcharts.com]] |accessdate=29 April 2013}} == Music, reception and legacy == ''[[The Guardian]]'' retrospectively qualified "Arabian Knights" as a "[[pop music|pop]] marvel"{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2007/nov/21/1000tohearbeforeyoudie5 |title=Artists Beginning with S | Music | The Guardian |last=Petridis |first=Alex |date=21 November 2007 |website=[[The Guardian]] |quote=Pop marvels such as Spellbound and Arabian Knights were poised, peerless exercises in magic realism that you could dance to. |accessdate=1 March 2015}} while [[AllMusic]] described it as "dreamy and gothy."[http://www.allmusic.com/song/arabian-knights-mt0005105933 Arabian Knights review]. Allmusic. Retrieved 18 March 2015. [[Billy Corgan]] of [[the Smashing Pumpkins]] selected it in his playlist in December 2014 when he talked about some of his favourite music on BBC radio.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04tt9td "6 music playlist Billy Corgan"]. BBC.co.uk. 7 December 2014. Retrieved 15-5-2015 == Cover versions== [[Paul Roland]] covered "Arabian Knights" on his 1992 album ''Strychnine'', and [[Icky Blossoms]] covered it in 2013.Gregory, Adams. [http://exclaim.ca/music/article/black_lips_icky_blossoms-mamas_dont_let_your_babies_grow_up_to_be_cowboys_arabian_knights "Black Lips / Icky Blossoms "Mamas Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to be Cowboys" / "Arabian Knights""]. Exclaim!. 1 April 2013. Retrieved 26 December 2015 == Track listing == ; 7" {{track listing | headline = Side A | title1 = Arabian Knights | length1 = 3:08 }} {{track listing | headline = Side B | title1 = "[[Supernatural Thing (song)|Supernatural Thing]]" | length1 = 4:26 }} ; 12" {{track listing | headline = Side A | title1 = Arabian Knights | length1 = 3:09 }} {{track listing | headline = Side B | title1 = Supernatural Thing | length1 = 4:26 | title2 = Congo Conga | length2 = 4:14 }} {{track listing | collapsed = yes | headline = US bonus track | title3 = Slap Dash Slap | length3 = 3:41 }} == Charts == {| class="wikitable" !Chart (1981) !Peak
position |- |[[UK Singles Chart]][http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/17098/siouxsie-and-the-banshees/ "Siouxsie and the Banshees - UK Singles Chart"]. OfficialCharts. Retrieved 10 October 2015. |align="center"|32 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Siouxsie and the Banshees}} [[Category:1981 singles]] [[Category:Songs about Asia]] [[Category:Songs based on fairy tales]] [[Category:Siouxsie and the Banshees songs]] [[Category:Polydor Records singles]] [[Category:Music based on One Thousand and One Nights]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Nigel Gray]] [[Category:1981 songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Siouxsie Sioux]] [[Category:Songs written by Steven Severin]] [[Category:Songs written by John McGeoch]] [[Category:Songs written by Budgie (musician)]]

page.title: Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians | abbreviation = AACM | motto = | predecessor = Experimental Band | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date|1965|05|df=y}} | founder = Muhal Richard Abrams, Jodie Christian, Steve McCall, Phil Cohran | extinction = <!-- e.g. use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = Non-profit organization | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for non-profit org) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = Support and encourage jazz performers, composers and educators | headquarters = | location = Chicago, Illinois | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | region = U.S. | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | language = English | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = Henry Threadgill, Anthony Braxton, Jack DeJohnette | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | affiliations = Black Artists' Group | budget = | revenue = | disbursements = | expenses = | endowment = MacArthur Foundation | slogan = | website = {{URL|aacmchicago.org}} }}
The '''Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians''' ('''AACM''') is a [[non-profit organization]], founded in 1965 in Chicago by pianist [[Muhal Richard Abrams]], pianist [[Jodie Christian]], drummer [[Steve McCall (drummer)|Steve McCall]], and composer [[Phil Cohran]].<ref name="RCJE">{{Cite book| last = Cook| first = Richard| author-link =| year = 2005| title = Richard Cook's Jazz Encyclopedia| publisher = Penguin Books| location = London| isbn = 0-141-00646-3| page = 23}}</ref> The AACM is devoted "to nurturing, performing, and recording serious, original music," according to its charter. It supports and encourages [[jazz]] performers, composers and educators. Although founded in the jazz tradition, the group's outreach and influence has, according to Larry Blumenfeld, "touched nearly all corners of modern music."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/free-at-first-the-audacious-journey-of-the-association-for-the-advancement-of-creative-musicians-review-1429654559|title='Free at First: The Audacious Journey of the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians' Review|author=Blumenfeld, Larry |date=April 21, 2015|work=Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
==Background== By the 1960s jazz music was losing ground to rock music and the founders of the AACM felt that a proactive group of musicians would add creativity and outlet for new music.<ref name=Reich>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/reich/ct-jazz-aacm-20150127-column.html|title=50th anniversary of AACM celebrated at DuSable Museum|author=Reich, Howard|date=January 27, 2015|work=Chicago Tribune}}</ref> The AACM was formed in May 1965 by a group of musicians centered on [[pianist]] [[Muhal Richard Abrams]] who had organized an Experimental Band since 1962. The musicians were generally steadfast in their commitment to their music, despite a lack of performance venues and sometimes indifferent audiences. From 1969 the AACM organised a music education program for inner-city youths.<ref>{{cite book|author=Litweiler, John | title=The Freedom Principle: Jazz After 1958 | publisher=Da Capo | year=1984|isbn=0-306-80377-1}}</ref> In the 1960s and 1970s AACM members were among the most important and innovative in all of jazz, though the AACM's contemporary influence has waned some in recent years. Many AACM members have recorded widely: in the early days on the [[Delmark Records]] Avant Garde Jazz series and later on the [[Black Saint/Soul Note]] and [[India Navigation]] labels, and to a lesser extent on the [[Arista Records]] and [[ECM (record label)|ECM]] labels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.delmark.com/delmark.history.htm|title=Delmark History|work=delmark.com}}</ref>
The musical endeavors of members of the AACM often include an adventurous mixing of avant-garde jazz, classical, and world music. The AACM also ran a school, The AACM School of Music, with classes in all areas taught by members of the AACM. The AACM also had a strong relationship with an influential sister organization, the [[Black Artists' Group]] (BAG) of [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. The AACM has received aid from the [[MacArthur Foundation]] and has a strong relationship with [[Columbia College Chicago|Columbia College]]. ''A Power Stronger Than Itself: The Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians'' by [[George Lewis (trombonist)|George Lewis]], has been published by the University of Chicago Press (May 2008).<ref name="nyt_2008">{{Cite news | first = Nate | last=Chinen | title=Four Decades of Music That Redefined Free | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=May 2, 2008 | accessdate=June 7, 2012 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/02/arts/music/02aacm.html}}</ref>
In 2015, a 50-year retrospective exhibition of art, music and group-related artifacts, entitled, "Free at First", was held at the [[DuSable Museum of African American History]].<ref name=Reich/>
==Music== The AACM has been on the forefront of the avant-garde since its inception in 1965. [[Anthony Braxton]], [[Henry Threadgill]], and the [[Art Ensemble of Chicago]] pushed the boundaries of jazz and challenged the avant-garde classical movement led by [[John Cage]]. Concerts were heavily improvised, and many AACM members created scores that blended music, geometry, painting, and ciphers to be interpreted by the performers live. The AACM was part of an artistic movement on the South Side of Chicago that included AFRICobra (African Commune of Bad Relevant Artists) and other collectives.<ref>Lewis, George E.. "Improvised Music After 1950: Afrological and Eurological Perspectives".Black Music Research Journal 22 (2002): 215–246</ref>
== Members == {{expand list|date=June 2017}} {{div col}} * [[Muhal Richard Abrams]] * [[Fred Anderson (musician)|Fred Anderson]] * [[Harrison Bankhead]] * [[Mwata Bowden]] * [[Lester Bowie]] * [[Anthony Braxton]] * [[Ari Brown]] * [[Jodie Christian]] * [[Charles Clark (musician)|Charles Clark]] * [[Phil Cohran]] * [[Iqua Colson]] * [[Isaiah Collier]] * [[Jeremiah Collier]] * [[Pete Cosey]] * [[Ernest Dawkins]] * [[Jack DeJohnette]]<ref name="Kelsey">{{cite web |last1=Kelsey |first1=Chris |title=The Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-association-for-the-advancement-of-creative-musicians-mn0001286033/biography |website=AllMusic |accessdate=26 June 2018}}</ref> * [[Kahil El'Zabar]] * [[Douglas Ewart]] * [[Malachi Favors]] * [[Alvin Fielder]] * [[Chico Freeman]] * Vandy Harris<ref name="Kelsey" /> * [[Fred Hopkins]] * [[Joseph Jarman]] * [[Leroy Jenkins (jazz musician)|Leroy Jenkins]] * [[George Lewis (trombonist)|George Lewis]] * [[Steve McCall (drummer)|Steve McCall]] * [[Kalaparusha Maurice McIntyre]] * [[Nicole Mitchell (musician)|Nicole Mitchell]]<ref name="nyt_2008"/> * [[Roscoe Mitchell]] * [[Don Moye]] * [[Amina Claudine Myers]] * [[Reggie Nicholson]] * [[Jeff Parker (musician)|Jeff Parker]] * [[Junius Paul]] * [[Mike Reed (musician)|Mike Reed]]<ref name="Reed">[http://www.mikereed-music.com/about Bio] at Mike Reed website.</ref> * [[Tomeka Reid]] * [[Matana Roberts]] * [[Rasul Siddik]] * [[Wadada Leo Smith]] * [[Henry Threadgill]] * [[Edward Wilkerson]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Lewis |first=George E. |title=A Power Stronger Than Itself: The AACM and American Experimental Music |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago |year=2008 |isbn=0226477037}} * Reich, Howard. "Revolution in sound". ''Chicago Tribune''. March 1, 2015, section 4, page 1. * Kot, Greg. "AACM's spirit endures in underground rock". ''Chicago Tribune''. March 1, 2015, section 4, page 1.
==External links== * [http://www.aacmchicago.org/ Official site] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/02/arts/music/02aacm.html?ref=music Profile in ''The New York Times'' May 2008] * [http://www.sweetpeareview.com/sweets13.html Essay on "A Power Stronger Than Itself" at ''Sweet Pea Review'']

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |image = Replace this image female.svg |image_size = 150px |name = Ayala Zacks-Abramov
אילה זקס-אברמוב |caption = |birth_date = 1912 |birth_place = [[Jerusalem]], [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandate for Palestine]] (now [[Israel]]) |death_date = August 30, 2011 |death_place = [[Israel]] |occupation = [[art collector]] |children = |nationality = [[Israelis|Israeli]]
[[Canadians|Canadian]] }} '''Ayala Zacks-Abramov''' ({{lang-he|אילה זקס-אברמוב}}, 1912 – 30 August 2011) was an [[Israel]]i-[[Canadians|Canadian]][http://www.artlyst.com/articles/canadas-peggy-guggenheim-ayala-zacksabramov-dies Canada's Peggy Guggenheim Ayala Zacks-Abramov Dies - ArtLyst] [[art collector]]. Ayala was widowed three times, and was previously married to the Canadian art collector Samuel Jacob Zacks and to the knesset member [[Zalman Abramov]]. ==Biography== Zacks-Abramov was born in Jerusalem in 1912 as Ayala Ben-Tovim. Her parents, Shmuel Ben-Tovim and Rashe (née: Berman) were married in Jerusalem in 1902. She studied in London and in Paris where she met her first husband, Morris Fleg, whom she married in 1938. In 1940, during [[World War II]], he joined the [[French Resistance]] after Fleg enlisted to the army and was killed during a military operation. In 1947, she married Samuel Zacks, a Canadian economist and art collector, whom she met during her stay in [[Switzerland]]. After marrying, the couple began to collect art items from the 19th century and the 20th century, mainly of French, Canadian and Israeli artists such as [[Gauguin]], [[Auguste Rodin|Rodin]], [[Picasso]], [[Henri Matisse]], [[Wassily Kandinsky|Kandinsky]] and [[Chagall]]. They also acquired art by Israeli artists such as [[Marcel Janco]], [[Mordechai Ardon]], [[Reuven Rubin]] and [[Anna Ticho]], and art of relatively unknown artists at the time of the purchase such as [[Ofer Lellouche]], [[Yigal Tumarkin]] and [[Joseph Zaritsky]]. In 1970, her husband Zacks died. She returned to Israel in 1976 and married Zalman Abramov, who was a lawyer and a Knesset member.[http://www.haaretz.co.il/gallery/1.1373523 מתה פטרונית האמנות אילה זקס אברמוב - גלריה - הארץ] The couple were [[Patronage|patrons of the arts]], and Abramov continued to support the art world even after her husband's death in 1997. Zachs-Abramov supported over the years the [[Tel Aviv Museum of Art]] and the [[Israel Museum]] and had a hand in their growth. Both the museums have halls named after her. She mentioned these museums in her will, in which she declared that her art collection would be divided between them. The Israeli notable painter [[Joseph Zaritsky]] painted a well-known figurative portrait of her. Many of the art works in Zachs-Abramov's possession were donated or loaned through to years to museums in Israel, France and Canada. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.artlyst.com/articles/canadas-peggy-guggenheim-ayala-zacksabramov-dies Canada's Peggy Guggenheim Ayala Zacks-Abramov Dies] - published on artlyst.com * [http://www.haaretz.co.il/gallery/1.1373523 The art patron Ayala Zacks Abramov died] - published on [[Haaretz]] on August 30, 2011 {{he icon}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zacks-Abramov, Ayala}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Israeli art collectors]] [[Category:Israeli art]] [[Category:Burials at the Jewish cemetery on the Mount of Olives]]

{{For|the action of slapping in the face with the front of the hand|Bitch slap}} {{lead too short|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox film | name = Bitch Slap | image = Bitch slap poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Rick Jacobson]] | producer = Eric Gruendemann
[[Rick Jacobson]] | writer = Eric Gruendemann
[[Rick Jacobson]] | starring = [[Julia Voth]]
[[Erin Cummings]]
[[America Olivo]]
[[Michael Hurst]]
[[Minae Noji]]
[[Lucy Lawless]]
[[Kevin Sorbo]]
[[Renee O'Connor]] | music = [[John R. Graham (composer)|John R. Graham]] | cinematography = Stuart Asbjornsen | editing = Joe McFadden
Corey Yaktus | studio = Epic Slap[http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18357 'Bitch Slap' Girls Gone Wild Promo Spot!] (Video) | distributor = [[Freestyle Releasing]]http://freestylereleasing.com/bitch-slap/
[[IM Global]]
[[Summit Entertainment]] (USA)
[[Momentum Pictures]] (UK) | released = {{Film date|2009|09|14|Toronto International Film Festival}} | runtime = 109 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $514,537 }} '''''Bitch Slap''''' is a 2009 action film directed by [[Rick Jacobson]]{{cite web | author = Sean Decker | url = http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/35257/excl-filmmakers-and-stars-talk-bitch-slap | title = EXCL: Filmmakers and Stars Talk Bitch Slap! | work = Dread Central }} and stars [[Julia Voth]], [[Erin Cummings]], [[America Olivo]] and [[Michael Hurst]], with cameos by [[Lucy Lawless]], [[Kevin Sorbo]], and [[Renee O'Connor]].[http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18613 News Bites: 'Demons' BBC Record Opening, 'Bitch Slap' Poster Designs & 'Penance' Clip] Bloody-Disgusting.com January 6, 2010 == Plot == Three girls, a down-and-out [[stripper]] named Trixie, a drug-running killer and [[ex-convict]] named Camero, and a corporate powerbroker nicknamed Hel, arrive at a remote desert hideaway to extort massive riches from a ruthless sword-wielding killer named Pinky, who is also a notorious underworld figure. None of the three women is who they appear to be: each has an ulterior motive. They kidnap a gangster called Gage and try to force him to reveal where the treasure is buried. He refuses, believing they will kill him anyway, but Hel promises he will not be harmed. Camero shoots him, against the wishes of Hel, saying she made no such promise. His phone rings, and they believe Gage is connected to Pinky. Things become more complicated when a police officer named Deputy Fuchs arrives. Unknown to them, he was in the audience five nights ago when Trixie performed as a stripper to seduce Gage. However, the three women hide the body and are able to convince Fuchs to leave. While digging for the treasure, Camero asks the girls about the best sex each has ever had, believing the answer tells her something important about their character. She admits her best sex ever was with a circus [[contortionist]], although she did not even know the contortionist's name. During a water fight, Trixie falls onto something in the sand. They dig; however, instead of buried treasure they find the dead body of one of Hel's contacts. Trixie goes into the trailer to collect herself as Hel follows her to check on her, only for Trixie to seduce Hel into kissing her, which leads to them having sex until Camero catches them in the act. They are interrupted by Hot Wire and his girlfriend Kinki, whom Camero is familiar with. At gunpoint, the two abuse the women and force them to dig for the buried treasure. Deputy Fuchs returns and attempts to save the women, but instead creates a gunfight, which Hel ends with a high-powered machine gun found in the nearby trailer. Camero asks the meaning of the code Hel uses on the bunker "75650". At closer inspection it appears that the number 1 is associated with the letter A, 2 with BCD, 3 with E, 4 is with FGH, 5 is with IJK, 6 is with LMN, 7 is with OPQ, 8 is with RST, 9 is with UVW and 0 is with XYZ. With this info the code numbers spell "PINKY" Hel and Trixie find a concealed bunker full of goods stolen from Pinky, including a mysterious weapon, diamonds, and a beautiful sword, which Trixie takes. Camero, believing she is in the midst of a double-cross, fights Hel for the diamonds. Camero overcomes Hel and sets Trixie afire along with barrels of flammable liquids. Camero leaves Hel in chains while she attempts to drive away with the diamonds; however, Hel quickly uses the super-machine gun to free herself, and fires a rocket that destroys the car Camero was driving. Hel admits to Trixie that she is a secret agent who reports to a man named Phoenix, and that she is on a mission to retrieve the weapon they found in Pinky's lair. Camero returns and again fights Hel. After she beats Hel to the ground, Camero assumes she is dead and moves to kill Trixie. As Trixie will not fight back, Camero attempts to rape her, but stops when she sees a tattoo and realizes Trixie was the mysterious contortionist from her past. Before she can kill Trixie, Camero is shot in the back and killed by Deputy Fuchs, who managed to survive the explosion. However, instead of thanking him, Trixie kills Fuchs using a hidden [[Shuriken|throwing star]]. Hel awakens, having survived Camero's attack. Trixie then reveals that she, in fact, is Pinky, and concocted the entire plot to retrieve the sword she took from Gage's bunker, which he had taken from her six months previously. == Cast == [[File:JuliaVothErinCummings09TIFF.jpg|thumb|right|Voth and Cummings at the [[2009 Toronto International Film Festival]]]] * [[Julia Voth]] as Trixie * [[Erin Cummings]] as Hel * [[America Olivo]] as Camero, and Sister Prudence Bangtail * [[Michael Hurst]] as Gage * [[Ron Melendez]] as Deputy Fuchs * [[William Gregory Lee]] as Hot Wire * [[Minae Noji]] as Kinki * Scott Hanley as Black Ice * [[Kevin Sorbo]] as Mr. Phoenix * Dennis Keiffer as MacDaddy * [[Lucy Lawless]] as Mother Superior * [[Renee O'Connor]] as Sister Batrill * [[Mark Lutz (actor)|Mark Lutz]] as Deiter Von Vondervon * [[Debbie Lee Carrington]] as Hot Pocket * [[Zoë Bell]] as Rawhide == Music == [[John R. Graham (composer)|John R. Graham]] composed the musical score and the CD was released in 2009; featuring 29 songs. The film also features songs by [[AM Conspiracy]], [[Rebel Vengeance]] and [[Eagles of Death Metal]].{{cite web | url = http://musicfromfilm.com/movies/bitchslap.php | title = Music from Bitch Slap | publisher = MusicfromFilm.com | date= | accessdate = 2010-11-16 }} == Release == The film was released in the [[United States]] on January 8, 2010 in theaters and video-on-demand. It received a limited run of three weeks in three theaters and closed January 21. {{Anchor|Box office}} The film grossed $17,365 at the domestic (US and Canada) box office and $199,436 foreign.{{cite web| date = 2010-01-16| title = Bitch Slap| url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=bitchslap.htm| work = [[Box Office Mojo]]| publisher = Amazon.com| accessdate = 2010-03-11}} === Home media === {{Anchor|DVD|Video}} An unrated DVD was released on March 2, 2010 in the United States.{{cite web| author = MattFini| title = Bitch Slap Pre-Release DVD Event| url = http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/36136/bitch-slap-pre-release-dvd-event| work = Dread Central}} === Critical response === {{Anchor|Critics}} [[Metacritic]] gave the film a score of 19% based on a weighted average of 5 reviews, indicating "Overwhelming dislike" from critics.{{metacritic film|bitch-slap}} [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave the film a score of 31% based on 16 reviews, where ratings below 60% are considered "Rotten".{{rotten-tomatoes|id=10010153-bitch_slap|title=Bitch Slap}} [[Flixster]] In ''[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]]'', IM Global's Stuart Ford described ''Bitch Slap'' as "a pure exploitation pic — chicks, boobs, guns and bad guys, in that order".{{cite news| date= May 8, 2009| first= Pamela |last= McClintock| title= Veterans share sales wisdom| url= http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118003370.html| work = [[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]]| accessdate=2010-03-11}} In ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', Joe Leydon wrote "Overblown and underwhelming, 'Bitch Slap' is a desperately unfunny attempt to satirically recycle cliches and archetypes from sexploitation actioners of the 1960s and '70s."{{cite news | date= September 22, 2009| last= Leydon |first= Joe| title= Bitch Slap| url= http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117941194.html| work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]| accessdate = 2010-01-08}} Amy Biancolli of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' wrote "The idea is to amuse anyone who's not offended by all the over-baked violence, bad acting and slapping babeage, but it's so heavy-handed and hyper-stylized that any extant wit gets smacked into submission. It's just not any fun."{{cite news | date = January 8, 2010| last = Biancolli |first = Amy| title = Review: 'Bitch Slap' flagellates itself| url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/01/07/MVQT1BEEBU.DTL| work = [[San Francisco Chronicle]]|accessdate = 2010-01-08}} Mark Olsen in the ''Los Angeles Times'' noted that, "Despite its obsession with décolletage, ''Bitch Slap'' is surprisingly puritanical (much teasing, no pleasing)."{{cite news| url = http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-capsules8-2010jan08,0,2678011.story| newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]]| last = Olsen | first = Mark| title = More decolletage than homage| date = January 8, 2010| accessdate = 2010-02-22 }} ==Inspiration== The film is described as "a post-modern, thinking man's throwback to the 'B' Movie/Exploitation films of the 1950s–70s as well as a loving, sly parody of the same".{{cite news| url = http://www.cinematical.com/2008/07/22/sdcc-exclusive-bitch-slap-poster-and-photos| title= SDCC Exclusive: 'Bitch Slap' Poster and Photos| last= Davis |first= Erik| date= 2008-07-22| work= Cinematical | accessdate=2008-07-22}} The film is inspired by the ''[[Dragstrip Girl]]'', ''[[Faster, Pussycat! Kill! Kill!]]'', ''[[Kung Fu Nun]]'', the pantheon of [[blaxploitation]] and other [[exploitation films]] which had a renewal in popularity after the cult success of ''[[Grindhouse (film)|Grindhouse]]'' in 2007.{{cite web| url = http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18199| title = Bloodied Hot Babes in New 'Bitch Slap' Photos}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.bitchslapmovie.com/}} * {{IMDb title|1212974|Bitch Slap}} * {{AllRovi movie|488355|Bitch Slap}} [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2000s action thriller films]] [[Category:Exploitation films]] [[Category:Girls with guns films]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]] [[Category:Summit Entertainment films]]

{{Infobox orchestra | name = Boston Modern Orchestra Project | image = | caption = | years_active = 1996–present | location = [[Boston]] | background = classical_ensemble | alias = BMOP | origin = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | genre = [[Contemporary classical music|Contemporary classical]] | principal_conductor = [[Gil Rose]] | website = {{URL|http://www.bmop.org}} }} The '''Boston Modern Orchestra Project''' (BMOP) is a professional [[orchestra]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]].
Founded in 1996 by artistic director [[Gil Rose]], its mission is to explore the connections between contemporary music and contemporary society by reuniting composers and audiences in a shared concert experience. In its first twelve seasons, BMOP performed over 80 concerts of contemporary orchestral music, commissioned more than 20 works and presented over 70 world premieres, released 20 CDs, produced the inaugural Ditson Festival of Contemporary Music with the [[Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston]], and collaborated to produce performances of contemporary operas (including the Opera Unlimited festival of contemporary chamber opera). Now entering its 20th season, it has released nearly 50 CDs in total. BMOP performs regularly at Boston's [[Jordan Hall]], and has performed in major venues on both the [[East Coast of the United States|East]] and [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]]s of the United States. BMOP has appeared at [[Tanglewood]], the Festival of New American Music in Sacramento, California, and Pittsburgh's "Music on the Edge" festival.
The orchestra has won the [[ASCAP]] Award for Adventurous Programming of Orchestral Music and recipient of the John S. Edwards Award for Strongest Commitment to New American Music.<ref>[ASCAP Orchestra Awards 2009 http://www.ascap.com/press/2009/0611_orchestra_awards.aspx]</ref><ref>[ASCAP Orchestra Awards 2010 http://www.ascap.com/press/2010/0618_Orchestra-Awards.aspx]</ref> In 2015 it was named Musical America's 2016 Ensemble of the Year, the first ever symphony orchestra to receive the award.<ref name="musical america 2015">{{cite news |last=Elliott |first=Susan |url=http://www.musicalamerica.com/news/newsstory.cfm?storyid=34958&categoryid=2&archived=0 |title=Musical America announces 2016 Artists of the Year |work=Musical America Worldwide |date=2015-10-14 |accessdate=2015-10-15}}</ref>
In 2008, BMOP launched its record label, BMOP/sound, with John Harbison’s ballet "Ulysses". Its composer-centric releases focus on orchestral works that are otherwise unavailable in recorded form. Its five inaugural releases appeared on the "Best of 2008" lists of [[The New York Times]], [[The Boston Globe]], [[National Public Radio]], [[Time Out (company)|Time Out]] New York, [[Down Beat]] magazine, and American Record Guide.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/ref/arts/2008holidayclassical.html "2008 Holiday Gift Guide: Best Classical CDs]</ref><ref>[http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/opera-classical/69919/classical-the-best-and-worst-of-2008 "Classical: The best (and worst) of 2008"]</ref> BMOP/sound has received two Grammy award nominations: in 2009 for its recording of [[Charles Fussell]]’s ''Wilde'' symphony for baritone and orchestra ([[Sanford Sylvan]] Best Classical Vocal Performance), and in 2010 for its recording of Derek Bermel's "Voices" for solo clarinet and orchestra (Best Instrumental Soloist Performance with Orchestra). [[The New York Times]] proclaimed, “BMOP/sound is an example of everything done right."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/21/arts/music/21stev.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Independent%20Labels%20Embrace%20a%20D.I.Y.%20Ethos&st=cse Steve Smith, ''Independent Labels Embrace a D.I.Y. Ethos'', The New York Times, 21 December 2008]</ref>
BMOP has hosted a Composer in Residence each season since 2000. In recognition of the importance of this position, [[Meet the Composer]] and the [[League of American Orchestras]] awarded BMOP one of six three-year Music Alive grants for a collaboration with composer Lisa Bielawa.<ref>[http://www.berkshirefinearts.com/index.php?page=article&article_id=1082&catID=8 Erica H. Adams, ''Boston Modern Orchestra Project (BMOP) Enlivens Audiences and Completes 12th Season with Five World Premieres'', BerkshireFineArts.com, 25 May 2009]</ref>
[[The New York Times]] said in 2000: "Mr. Rose and his team filled the music with rich, decisive ensemble colors and magnificent solos. These musicians were rapturous - superb instrumentalists at work and play."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/30/arts/music-review-poetry-in-songs-reflecting-sun-and-moon.html Paul Griffiths, ''Poetry in Songs Reflecting Sun and Moon'', The New York Times, 30 March 2000]</ref> Composer [[John Harbison]] has said that “No other city has anything resembling BMOP — with that level of activity, with that sustained productivity ... There’s really been no new-music organization with a wider range of inclusion.”<ref name="boston globe 2015-10-15">{{cite news |last=Weininger |first=David |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/2015/10/15/gil-rose-bmop-celebrate-years-audacity-excellence/lq3j6VLAfNOjaWLkTnBBhJ/story.html |title=Gil Rose, BMOP celebrate 20 years of audacity, excellence |work=[[Boston Globe]] |location=Boston, Mass. |date=2015-10-15 |accessdate=2015-10-15 }}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.bmop.org/ Boston Modern Orchestra Project site] *[http://www.gilrose.info/ Gil Rose site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061001182636/http://artofthestates.org/cgi-bin/performer.pl?ens=52 Art of the States: Boston Modern Orchestra Project] six works performed by the orchestra *[http://www.artseditor.com/html/march02/mar02_bmop.shtml ''A Bold Declaration: experiencing BMOP's modern music''] 2002 ArtsEditor.com feature article

{{For|the 2009 film|Brief Interviews with Hideous Men (film)}} {{Infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Brief Interviews with Hideous Men | title_orig = | image = Brief Interviews with Hideous Men cover.jpg | caption = First Edition hardcover | author = [[David Foster Wallace]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = John Fulbrook III | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Short story]] | publisher = [[Little, Brown and Company]] | pub_date = May 28, 1999 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print (hardback & paperback) | pages = 288 pp | isbn = 0-316-92541-1 | dewey= 813/.54 21 | congress= PS3573.A425635 B65 1999 | oclc= 40354776 }}
'''''Brief Interviews with Hideous Men''''' (1999) is a collection of 23 short stories by American writer [[David Foster Wallace]]. Four of the stories are entitled "Brief Interviews with Hideous Men" and are presented as transcripts of interviews with male subjects. The interviewer's questions are omitted from the transcripts, rendered merely as "Q." These stories and the rest of the collection are characterized by dark dry humor, alienation, and unconventional sexuality.
In 1997 Wallace was awarded the [[Aga Khan Prize for Fiction]] by editors of'' [[The Paris Review]]'' for "Brief Interviews with Hideous Men #6", which had appeared in the magazine and appears as "Brief Interviews with Hideous Men #20" in the collection.
Twelve of the "Interviews" were adapted into a stage play (''Hideous Men'') by [[Dylan McCullough]] in 2000, marking the first theatrical adaptation of any of Wallace's works. McCullough directed the premiere at the New York International Fringe Festival in August 2000.
In August 2012 British artists [[Andy Holden (artist)|Andy Holden]] and [http://www.davidraymondconroy.co.uk/ David Raymond Conroy] presented a stage adaptation of the book at the [[Institute of Contemporary Arts|ICA]], London,<ref>https://www.ica.org.uk/blog/andy-holden-and-david-raymond-conroy-conversation-anna-gritz</ref> which later toured to [[Arnolfini]], Bristol.<ref>http://www.arnolfini.org.uk/whatson/brief-interviews-with-hideous-men</ref> The production used a variety of multimedia techniques such as projection of the letter 'Q' on a backdrop that disrupted the monologues and a system of ear-pieces and auto-cues to convey the script to the actors on stage. The adaptation used four of the interviews and one short story and contained new music by [[Andy Holden (artist)|the Grubby Mitts.]]
21 of the interviews and stories were adapted and directed by David McGuff for Yellow Lab Productions entitled "Brief Interviews with Hideous Men." The production ran three nights, August 28–30, 2014, at the Hill Country Arts Foundation's Point Theater on the Elizabeth Huth Coates indoor stage.
[[John Krasinski]] adapted and directed [[Brief Interviews with Hideous Men (film)|a film version]] on the "Brief Interviews" stories that was released in 2009. [[Julianne Nicholson]] plays Sara Quinn, the interviewer unnamed in the stories.
==List of stories==
* "A Radically Condensed History of Postindustrial Life" * "Death Is Not the End" * "Forever Overhead" * "Brief Interviews with Hideous Men" * "Yet Another Example of the Porousness of Certain Borders (XI)" * "The Depressed Person" * "The Devil Is a Busy Man" * "Think" * "Signifying Nothing" * "Brief Interviews with Hideous Men" * "''Datum Centurio"'' * "Octet" * "Adult World (I)" * "Adult World (II)" * "The Devil Is a Busy Man" * "Church Not Made with Hands" * "Yet Another Example of the Porousness of Certain Borders (VI)" * "Brief Interviews with Hideous Men" * "Tri-Stan: I Sold Sissee Nar to Ecko" * "On His Deathbed, Holding Your Hand, the Acclaimed New Young Off-Broadway Playwright's Father Begs a Boon" * "Suicide as a Sort of Present" * "Brief Interviews with Hideous Men" * "Yet Another Example of the Porousness of Certain Borders (XXIV)"
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *

{{story-collection-stub}}

'''Central Asian art''' is [[visual art]] created in [[Central Asia]] by the largely [[Turkic peoples]] of modern [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Tajikistan]], [[Mongolia]], [[Tibet]], [[Afghanistan]], [[Pakistan]] and parts of China and Russia.<ref name="1a">{{cite book|author=Tamara Talbot Rice|title=Visual Arts|date=July 2011|accessdate=May 17, 2012|publisher=Oxford}}</ref><ref name="1b">{{cite book|author=Fahir İz|title=Central Asian Literature|date=|accessdate=May 17, 2012|publisher=}}</ref> The arts of recent centuries are mainly influenced by [[Islamic art]], but the varied earlier cultures were influenced by the art of China, Persia and Greece, as well as the [[Animal style]] that developed among the nomadic peoples of the [[steppe]]s.<ref name="1c">Encyclopædia Britannica, [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/102325/Central-Asian-arts Central Asian Arts]. 2012. Retrieved May 17, 2012. Encyclopædia Britannica.</ref> The [[Silk Road transmission of art]], [[Scythian art]], [[Greco-Buddhist art]], [[Serindian art]] and more recently [[Persianate]] culture, are all part of this complicated history.
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/33392/rec/2 Along the ancient silk routes: Central Asian art from the West Berlin State Museums], an exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art (fully available online as PDF)
[[Category:Asian art]] [[Category:Central Asia]]
